results.title: Blood alley
results.creator_credit: John Wayne, Warner Bros Pictures and William Wellman
results.brief_description: Big hearted, iron fisted and patriotic, Wilder (Wayne) braves dangerous waters pursuing Red Chinese forces as he steers a boatload of Chinese refugees along the 300 mile waterway called Blood Alley to freedom’s shores. Joining Wayne is Lauren Bacall who - for the first time - plays a rough outdoor role. Wayne’s role was originally meant for Robert Mitchum, but he was fired from the film after an altercation in which he shoved director William A. Wellman into San Francisco Bay. Music by Roy Webb. Written by A.S. Fleischman.

results.title: Blood-borne pathogens in the workplace
results.brief_description: Blood-borne pathogens are microorganisms which can cause disease. They can be found in infected blood and bodily fluids. Diseases which can be spread by blood-borne pathogens include malaria and syphilis, but today, the most common are Hepatitis B and AIDS. This program gives clear, practical information on what blood-borne pathogens are, how they can (and can’t) be transmitted, what you can do to reduce the risk of transmission in the workplace, and how to minimise risk if you are exposed to a blood-borne pathogen due to an accident. Made with the support of the Infection Control Department, Fairfield Hospital.

results.brief_description: The nature and the function of the blood, with particular stress on the red and white corpuscles and the plasma is explained by use of animation and live action.

results.title: Blondie live!
results.creator_credit: KMW Productions, Stan Harris and Ken Weinstock
results.brief_description: Recorded in Toronto, just prior to their break-up, this live concert by New Wave rock group “Blondie” includes the songs “Rapture”, “Island of lost souls”, “Danceway”, “The Tide is high”, “Heart of glass”, “Hanging on the telephone”, “Dreaming”, “One way or another”, “War child”, “Start me up” and “Call me”. Captured at the peak of their fame, this presents “Blondie” as a fantastic live pop group, with a slew of catchy hits in their repertoire. Blondie are: Debbie Harry (vocals), Clem Burke (drums), James Destri (keyboards), Nigel Harrison (bass guitar), Chris Stein (guitar) and featuring Eddie Martinez on jazz guitar.

results.title: Blonde venus
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures and Josef von Sternberg
results.brief_description: Marlene Dietrich plays the wife of a scientist who sacrifices her stage career for marriage and motherhood. When her scientist husband (Herbert Marshall) is diagnosed with radium poisoning, she returns to the stage as a cabaret singer to finance his costly medical treatment. On her opening night, she meets a wealthy playboy (Cary Grant) who gives her enough money to pay for her husband’s treatment abroad. When her husband returns, he suspect that she has been unfaithful and forces her to leave their home. Unwilling to abandon her 5 year old son (Dickie Moore) she flees to the South with him, pursued by the law. Josef von Sternberg exposes the problems faced by women attempting to assert their independence in a society which places them at the mercy of husbands, employers and the law. Screenplay by Jules Furthman and S. K. Lauren.

results.title: Blokes and sheds - Silvio
results.creator_credit: Sarah Wishart, Robi Watt, Mark Thomson, Australian Film Commission, South Australian Film Corporation and SBS Independent
results.brief_description:
One of 12 minidocos about blokes and their sheds in South Australia.
In the scenic Adelaide Hills, Silvio, a well-known sculptor, spends all of his time working in his shed. He tells us how he and his family came to grow up in Australia after his father was a Hungarian pilot for the Germans in the war. Silvio began carving when he was five years old, carving bark off pine trees, soap, and bits of wood. He now creates life-sized beautifully ornate carved animals…pelicans, lizards and frogs from wood, stone and bronze. We see Silvio working with true commitment and passion in his enormous shed, as he works on creating the animals that he loves. Based on the book by Mark Thomson.

results.title: Blokes and sheds - Saroop & Omer
results.creator_credit: Sarah Wishart, Robi Watt, Mark Thomson, Australian Film Commission, South Australian Film Corporation and SBS Independent
results.brief_description:
One of 12 minidocos about blokes and their sheds in South Australia.
Set in the lush Riverland in South Australia, we meet a Sikh man, Saroop, and his Bosnian friend, Omer. Saroop owns 400 acres of fruit growing land on the River Murray. He’s been there for 25 years after coming out from the Punjab. Saroop has several sheds with large tractors and spraying machinery as well as one open-sided shed where he and Omer work on repairing things and on long term experiments - such as the budcutting machine they have worked on for several years. They call this shed “Omer’s Lab”. Saroop and Omer work hard at reusing lots of existing scrap to construct new things and replace parts on others. They are extremely inventive and are proud they have saved hundreds of dollars by making things more mechanical and efficient. This interstitial explores the close friendship between two different cultural backgrounds. Based on the book by Mark Thomson.

results.title: Blokes and sheds - Ramy & John
results.creator_credit: Sarah Wishart, Robi Watt, Mark Thomson, Australian Film Commission, South Australian Film Corporation and SBS Independent
results.brief_description:
12 x 2 minute minidocos about blokes and their sheds in South Australia.
When Ramy, an Egyptian born inventor and engineer, needed someone to help him build a prototype paper making machine, he was put in touch with John, a ‘jack of all trades’ with a large farm shed in which all things were possible. And so their relationship was born. It gets stronger each day with a combination of true friendship and utmost professional admiration. The large shed, surrounded by beautiful native bushland in the Adelaide Hills, has many different projects underway: from old steam engines, dismembered motor bikes to pneumatically controlled guillotines and prototype lathes. We witness this teamwork, as Ramy and his older counterpart design, test and just generally find things to perfect in their shed, never losing their energy to find a solution. Based on the book by Mark Thomson.

results.title: Blokes and sheds - Phu & Phong
results.creator_credit: Sarah Wishart, Robi Watt, Mark Thomson, Australian Film Commission, South Australian Film Corporation and SBS Independent
results.brief_description:
One of 12 minidocos about blokes and their sheds in South Australia.
Phu and Phuong’s shed is a serious mechanical jewel box. The exterior, a classic corrugated shed, gives no real impression of what can be found inside. The shed houses both of the brother’s prized possessions – their cars. The boys weekends and most evenings are spent in the shed polishing and cleaning the beloved, gleaming machinery, listening to music and generally just being with the cars. Phu’s low and sleek Nissan Turbo has everything that can open and shut – all digital of course, with every ‘after market’ improvement possible. Electric blue LEDs glow, exotic dials flicker, buttons and knobs are there for the pressing and tweaking: it’s a bit like having a low-flying spaceship in a suburban shed. For Phu and Phuong, the shed has been there for most of their lives. As kids they watched their father looking after his cars in the shed, which created their own interest in shed activities. Surrounded by their father’s ornate topiary, the shed dominates their small backyard. It was built to cram in four cars, which makes the morning departures something of a family joke. The brothers enjoy taking their cars out for a cruise on Sunday but the best part is then returning for hours in the shed to polish and love it some more. Based on the book by Mark Thomson.

results.title: Blokes and sheds - Mick
results.creator_credit: Sarah Wishart, Robi Watt, Mark Thomson, Australian Film Commission, South Australian Film Corporation and SBS Independent
results.brief_description:
One of 12 minidocos about blokes and their sheds in South Australia.
Mick’s obsession with trains began when he was a young boy growing up in Prague. He began constructing his model train world for his grandchildren many years ago. However, when they grew up and lost interest, Mick’s interest continued to grow. Mick’s shed contains another world. In it are miniature houses, people, trees and animals, all set around a train line with a “Swiss” alpine backdrop complete with snow capped mountains. Mick spends his time in his shed perfecting his miniature world and making continuous repairs, additions and alterations. Based on the book by Mark Thomson.
